docs.lead_paragraph: Blood tests routinely given to most newborn babies throughout the United States in recent years do in fact appear to be greatly diminishing the incidence of cretinism, or hypothyroidism, in infants, according to a study published in The Lancet. A total of 63 babies who appeared normal at birth were identified as hypothyroid in a five-state New England regional program begun in 1977. All were treated for the condition in the first few weeks of life. All 63 received daily oral doses of thyroxine - the thyroid hormone they were lacking at birth. By age 3 or 4, their IQ's averaged a normal 106.
